subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: A small note on the Unicode proposal
msgSnippet:
I m not happy about it either, in fact I really dislike the solutions I
put forward (though I d prefer #2 over #1), but I can t see another ways
to meet all
messageBody:
I'm not happy about it either, in fact I really dislike the solutions I
put forward (though I'd prefer #2 over #1), but I can't see another ways
to meet all the criteria that Tim (implicitly) put forward in his
notepad example.

i.e.: Underline quikscript numbers in mixed script text using only one
font without any 'intelligence' (or as I prefer to call it 'artificial
stupidity') to determine which numbers should be underlined and which
should not.

If you use a font you can't choose which numbers will and won't be
underlined it's all or nothing.
And if you resort to rules and heuristics you can't use it in 'dumb'
apps like notepad.
Which leaves us with assigning code points - which has the parsing
problems we've just discussed.

Of course the other solution is, as you say, to simply to not bother
with the underline.
I'm afraid I have to agree with you, it's a lot of work to meet those
criteria for not much benefit.

oliver langan wrote:
>
> > You make a very good point about the underlined numbers, we either have
> > to create code points for underlined digits or an underline
> combining char.
> > The first will cost 3 bytes per digit and need 10 code points
> (obviously :).
> > The second will cost 4 bytes per digit but will only take one code point
> > and would allow other chars to be underlined - such as the commas in
> > 1,000,000.
> > Neither system would allow the digits to be properly parsed as numbers
> > by legacy programs though.
>
> Alternately, we could decide that the underlining or not of numbers is
> outside of the scope of the Unicode proposal. I don't like it,
> myself, and do not follow it when I write (or type) Quickscript:
> moreover, as you point out it would cause problems with machine
> parsing of the numbers. I think that the QS manual should be the
> 'first source' for the alphabet, but I don't think it necessarily
> needs to be followed slavishly.
>
> Now that I think about it, the underlining could be handled within the
> font. It would not be true underlining, but it would have a
> consistent look.
>
> oliver
>
>
